questions.question: A sweater originally priced at <math><mn>48</mn></math> dollars is on sale for <math><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math> off. What is the sale price of the sweater, in dollars?
questions.explanation: A <math><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math> discount means you pay <math><mn>75</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the original price. <math><mn>0.75</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>48</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>. Therefore, the sale price is <math><mn>36</mn></math> dollars.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember: 'x% off' means you pay (100-x)% of the original price. Multiply original price by (1 - x/100).

questions.question: If <math><mn>7</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>84</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Divide both sides by <math><mn>7</mn></math>: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Then subtract <math><mn>3</mn></math>: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For linear equations, isolate the variable by performing inverse operations. Always check your answer by plugging it back into the original equation.

questions.question_chart_description: A rectangular prism with length 8, width 5, and height 3.
questions.question: What is the volume, in cubic units, of a rectangular prism with length <math><mn>8</mn></math>, width <math><mn>5</mn></math>, and height <math><mn>3</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The volume of a rectangular prism is length × width × height. <math><mn>8</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize the basic volume formulas for common 3D shapes. For rectangular prisms, it's simply the product of the three dimensions.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A recipe for soup uses <math><mn>3</mn></math> cups of water for every <math><mn>2</mn></math> cups of lentils. If a large batch uses <math><mn>15</mn></math> cups of lentils, how many cups of water are needed?
questions.explanation: Set up the proportion <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>water</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>lentils</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. Let <math><mi>w</mi></math> be the cups of water. <math><mfrac><mi>w</mi><mn>15</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. Cross-multiply: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn></math>. So, <math><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>22.5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For ratio problems, keep the units consistent when setting up your proportion. The ratio of water to lentils must be equal in both the small and large batches.

questions.question: Which of the following expressions is equivalent to <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math> for all real numbers <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Notice that the expression is a quadratic in <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>: <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msup><mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. This factors as <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For expressions with only even powers of x, try substituting u = x² to see a simpler quadratic form that might be factorable.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question:
A system of equations and its solution are shown below.
Equation A: 4x+3y=19
Equation B: x-y=3
Solution: x=4,y=1
Which of the following statements verifies that x=4 and y=1 is the solution?

options.B: Substituting <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> satisfies both Equation A and Equation B.
options.D: Substituting <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> satisfies Equation A but not Equation B.

questions.explanation: A solution to a system of equations must satisfy every equation in the system. Check: For Equation A: <math><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>. For Equation B: <math><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Since both equations are true, (4,1) is a solution.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To verify a solution to a system, substitute the values into *all* original equations. If it makes even one equation false, it is not a solution.

questions.question: The price of a stock was <math><mi>d</mi></math> dollars on January 1. By March 1, the price had increased by <math><mn>40</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Between March 1 and May 1, the price decreased by <math><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. The price on May 1 was what percent of the price on January 1?
questions.explanation: Let the initial price be <math><mi>d</mi></math>. After a <math><mn>40</mn><mo>%</mo></math> increase, the price is <math><mn>1.4</mn><mi>d</mi></math>. A <math><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math> decrease from <math><mn>1.4</mn><mi>d</mi></math> means multiplying by <math><mn>0.75</mn></math>: <math><mn>1.4</mn><mi>d</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>0.75</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1.05</mn><mi>d</mi></math>. <math><mn>1.05</mn><mi>d</mi></math> is <math><mn>105</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of <math><mi>d</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For successive percentage changes, multiply by the decimal equivalents of the multipliers. An increase of x% means multiply by (1 + x/100). A decrease of y% means multiply by (1 - y/100).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='380' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='50' y1='280' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><path d='M50 56 Q200 456 350 56' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /><circle cx='50' cy='56' r='4' fill='black' /><text x='60' y='50' font-family='serif' font-size='12'>(0, 97/3)</text><circle cx='290' cy='184' r='4' fill='black' /><text x='300' y='180' font-family='serif' font-size='12'>(8, 11)</text><circle cx='200' cy='256' r='4' fill='red' /><text x='210' y='265' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>V</text><text x='370' y='240' font-family='serif' font-size='14' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='30' y='30' font-family='serif' font-size='14' font-style='italic'>y</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A parabola opening upwards in the xy-plane. The vertex V is the minimum point. The curve crosses the y-axis at (0, 97/3) and passes through the point (8, 11).
questions.question: The graph of the quadratic function <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi></math> is shown in the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane. The vertex of the parabola is at point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>V</mi></math>. If the axis of symmetry for the graph is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> and the parabola passes through the points <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>11</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mfrac><mn>97</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math>, what is the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate of the vertex <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>V</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
We use the vertex form of a quadratic function, f(x)=a(x-h)2+k, where (h,k) is the vertex. The axis of symmetry x=5 gives us h=5. We substitute the two given points to form a system of equations to solve for a and k.

1) Using point (8,11): 11=a(8-5)2+k→11=9a+k.
2) Using point (0,973): 973=a(0-5)2+k→973=25a+k.

Subtracting the first equation from the second: 973-11=16a→643=16a→a=43.
Finally, substitute a back into the first equation: 11=9(43)+k→11=12+k→k=-1.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='380' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='50' y1='280' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><path d='M50 56 Q200 456 350 56' stroke='lightgray' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='280' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5' /><text x='205' y='40' fill='green' font-family='serif' font-size='12'>Axis of Symmetry: x=5</text><circle cx='200' cy='256' r='4' fill='red' /><text x='210' y='265' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='red'>V (5, -1)</text><text x='370' y='240' font-family='serif' font-size='14' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='30' y='30' font-family='serif' font-size='14' font-style='italic'>y</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The graph illustrating the solution. The axis of symmetry at x=5 is highlighted with a green dashed line. The vertex V is plotted at (5, -1), confirming it is the minimum point of the parabola.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If you are given the axis of symmetry <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>h</mi></math>, immediately use the vertex form <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math> to reduce the number of unknowns.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='450' height='300' viewBox='0 0 450 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='450' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='420' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='180' y='290' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='14'>Number of Books</text><text x='15' y='150' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='14' transform='rotate(-90 15,150)'>Frequency</text><g fill='lightblue' stroke='black'><rect x='70' y='166' width='30' height='84' /><rect x='130' y='116' width='30' height='134' /><rect x='190' y='183' width='30' height='67' /><rect x='250' y='216' width='30' height='34' /><rect x='310' y='83' width='30' height='167' /><rect x='370' y='50' width='30' height='200' /></g><g font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'><text x='85' y='270'>0</text><text x='145' y='270'>1</text><text x='205' y='270'>2</text><text x='265' y='270'>3</text><text x='325' y='270'>4</text><text x='385' y='270'>5</text></g><g font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle' fill='black'><text x='85' y='160'>5</text><text x='145' y='110'>8</text><text x='205' y='178'>4</text><text x='265' y='210'>2</text><text x='325' y='78'>10</text><text x='385' y='45'>12</text></g></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A bar chart showing the frequency of books read. The x-axis represents the number of books (0 to 5) and the y-axis represents the frequency. The heights are: 0 books (5), 1 book (8), 2 books (4), 3 books (2), 4 books (10), 5 books (12).
questions.question: The bar chart above shows the distribution of the number of books read by <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>41</mn></math> students over the summer. What is the median number of books read?
questions.explanation:
To find the median of 41 students, we need to find the number of books read by the student in the 21st position (since 41+12=21). We calculate the cumulative frequency:
  • 0 books: 5 students (Positions 1-5)
  • 1 book: 5+8=13 students (Positions 6-13)
  • 2 books: 13+4=17 students (Positions 14-17)
  • 3 books: 17+2=19 students (Positions 18-19)
  • 4 books: 19+10=29 students (Positions 20-29)
The 21st student falls within the group that read 4 books. Therefore, the median is 4.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='450' height='300' viewBox='0 0 450 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='450' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='420' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='180' y='290' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='14'>Number of Books</text><g fill='lightgray' stroke='gray'><rect x='70' y='166' width='30' height='84' /><rect x='130' y='116' width='30' height='134' /><rect x='190' y='183' width='30' height='67' /><rect x='250' y='216' width='30' height='34' /></g><rect x='310' y='83' width='30' height='167' fill='red' stroke='black' /><rect x='370' y='50' width='30' height='200' fill='lightgray' stroke='gray' /><g font-family='sans-serif' font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'><text x='85' y='270'>0</text><text x='145' y='270'>1</text><text x='205' y='270'>2</text><text x='265' y='270'>3</text><text x='325' y='270' font-weight='bold' fill='red'>4</text><text x='385' y='270'>5</text></g><g font-family='sans-serif' font-size='11' text-anchor='middle' fill='blue'><text x='85' y='150'>Cum: 5</text><text x='145' y='100'>Cum: 13</text><text x='205' y='168'>Cum: 17</text><text x='265' y='200'>Cum: 19</text><text x='325' y='65' font-weight='bold' font-size='13'>Cum: 29</text><text x='385' y='35'>Cum: 41</text></g><text x='325' y='45' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='11' fill='red' text-anchor='middle'>Median (21st)</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The bar chart with the bar for '4 books' highlighted in red. Blue labels above the bars show the cumulative frequency (running total) at each step. The label above the '4 books' bar shows that the cumulative count reaches 29, meaning the 21st student is in this group.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find the median from a frequency graph, calculate the **Cumulative Frequency**. Add the counts bar by bar until you reach the middle position <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='300' viewBox='0 0 350 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,150 290,250 50,250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M50 230 L70 230 L70 250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><text x='35' y='150' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='300' y='260' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='30' y='265' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='25' y='200' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>5</text><text x='170' y='275' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>12</text><text x='180' y='190' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>?</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right triangle with the right angle at vertex C (bottom-left). The vertical side AC is labeled 5. The horizontal side CB is labeled 12. The hypotenuse AB is labeled with a question mark.
questions.question: In right triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is a right angle, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. What is the length of side <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Since <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>&#xtriangle;</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is a right triangle with the right angle at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi></math>, we use the Pythagorean theorem: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Plugging in the side lengths: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. This simplifies to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>25</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>144</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>169</mn></math>. Taking the square root gives <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>169</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='300' viewBox='0 0 350 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,150 290,250 50,250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M50 230 L70 230 L70 250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><line x1='50' y1='150' x2='290' y2='250' stroke='green' stroke-width='3' /><text x='35' y='150' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='300' y='260' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='30' y='265' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='25' y='200' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>5</text><text x='170' y='275' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>12</text><text x='180' y='190' fill='green' font-family='serif' font-weight='bold' font-size='16'>13</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same right triangle with the hypotenuse AB highlighted in green and labeled '13', showing the result of the Pythagorean theorem.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for **Pythagorean Triples** like <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>5</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>13</mn></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>8</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>17</mn></math> to save time on calculation.

questions.question: For what value of <math><mi>k</mi></math> does the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> have exactly one real solution?
questions.explanation: A quadratic equation <math><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> has exactly one real solution when its discriminant is zero: <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Here, <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></math>, <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. So, <math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math> → <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Only <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></math> is listed as an option.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The discriminant (b² - 4ac) determines the nature of the roots of a quadratic. One real solution (a double root) occurs when the discriminant equals zero.

questions.question: Which of the following represents all values of <math><mi>x</mi></math> that satisfy the inequality <math><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>></mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve step by step: <math><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>></mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Distribute: <math><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Subtract <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></math> from both sides: <math><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>></mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Add <math><mn>7</mn></math> to both sides: <math><mn>1</mn><mo>></mo><mi>x</mi></math>, which is equivalent to <math><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving inequalities, perform the same operations as with equations, but remember to reverse the inequality sign if you multiply or divide by a negative number.

questions.question: In a store, the price of a coat was first increased by <math><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and then decreased by <math><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. The final price was what percent of the original price?
questions.explanation: Let the original price be <math><mi>P</mi></math>. After a <math><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></math> increase, the price becomes <math><mn>1.2</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. A <math><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math> decrease from <math><mn>1.2</mn><mi>P</mi></math> means multiplying by <math><mn>0.75</mn></math>: <math><mn>1.2</mn><mi>P</mi><mo>×</mo><mn>0.75</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.9</mn><mi>P</mi></math>. <math><mn>0.9</mn><mi>P</mi></math> is <math><mn>90</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of <math><mi>P</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For successive percent changes, remember that the order matters. Always apply the percentage to the most recent value, not the original.

questions.question:
If (x,y) is a solution to the system of equations below, what is the value of x+y?
2x+3y=7
4x-y=7
questions.explanation: Add the two equations: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math> → Divide by 2: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. We want <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></math>. Subtract the second original equation from twice the first: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mn>7</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Substitute into <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math> → <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Sometimes you can find x+y without solving for x and y individually by adding or subtracting the equations strategically. For this system, solving directly is straightforward.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='150' cy='150' r='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none' opacity='0.3'/><path d='M150 150 L250 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 100 63.4 Z' fill='rgba(0, 0, 255, 0.1)' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M250 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 100 63.4' fill='none' stroke='blue' stroke-width='4'/><text x='160' y='120' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='blue'>Area = 12π</text><text x='210' y='70' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='blue'>Arc = 4π</text><text x='135' y='165' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>O</text><text x='260' y='155' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='90' y='55' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='160' y='145' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>?</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O. A shaded sector AOC is shown. The area of the sector is labeled 'Area = 12 pi' and the curved length of the outer edge is labeled 'Arc = 4 pi'. The central angle at O is marked with a question mark.
questions.question: In circle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi></math>, the length of minor arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi></math> and the area of sector <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. What is the measure of the central angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: We can relate the area of a sector and its arc length using the formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mtext>Area</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>r</mi><mo>×</mo><mtext>Arc Length</mtext></math>. Substituting the given values: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>r</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Simplifying gives <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>12</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi></math>, so the radius <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Next, we use the arc length formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mtext>Arc</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>θ</mi><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math>. Substituting the known values: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>θ</mi><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math>. This simplifies to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>θ</mi><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></math>, or <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>θ</mi><mn>360</mn></mfrac></math>. Solving for <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>θ</mi></math>, we get <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>120</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='150' cy='150' r='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none' opacity='0.3'/><path d='M150 150 L250 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 100 63.4 Z' fill='rgba(0, 255, 0, 0.1)' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M250 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 100 63.4' fill='none' stroke='green' stroke-width='4'/><text x='170' y='140' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='green'>r = 6</text><text x='140' y='130' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='green'>120°</text><text x='135' y='165' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>O</text><text x='260' y='155' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='90' y='55' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The circle with the solution values filled in. The radius is labeled 6 and the central angle is labeled 120 degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize the relationship <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mtext>Area</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>r</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>s</mi></math> (where <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>s</mi></math> is arc length). This lets you find the radius quickly without needing the angle first.

questions.question: A bag contains <math><mn>4</mn></math> red marbles and <math><mn>6</mn></math> blue marbles. Two marbles are drawn at random without replacement. What is the probability that both marbles are red?
questions.explanation: Probability the first marble is red: <math><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math>. Given that, there are now <math><mn>3</mn></math> red marbles left out of <math><mn>9</mn></math> total. Probability the second is red: <math><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. Multiply: <math><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>15</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For 'without replacement' probability, the total number of items and the number of favorable items change after each draw. Multiply the probabilities for each stage.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, where <math><mi>b</mi></math> and <math><mi>c</mi></math> are constants. If the graph of <math><mi>f</mi></math> has <math><mi>x</mi></math>-intercepts at <math><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>b</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: If the x-intercepts are at -2 and 6, the quadratic can be written in factored form: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Expanding: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>a</mi></math>. Comparing to <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, we see <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> (since the coefficient of <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> is 1). Therefore, <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a quadratic with given x-intercepts p and q, it can be written as f(x)=a(x-p)(x-q). Expand to find the coefficients in standard form.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrowhead' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='7' refX='0' refY='3.5' orient='auto'><polygon points='0 0, 10 3.5, 0 7' fill='black'/></marker></defs><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrowhead)'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrowhead)'/><line x1='50' y1='94' x2='290' y2='274' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='125' cy='150' r='5' fill='red'/><text x='135' y='145' font-size='14'>(3, a)</text><circle cx='225' cy='225' r='5' fill='red'/><text x='235' y='220' font-size='14'>(7, 1)</text><text x='340' y='280' font-size='14' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='20' y='60' font-size='14' font-style='italic'>y</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A coordinate plane showing a line with a negative slope passing through two marked points. One point is labeled (3, a) and the other is labeled (7, 1).
questions.question: The graph of linear function <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>f</mi></math> passes through points <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. The slope of the graph is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>. What is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>a</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
The slope formula is m=y2-y1x2-x1.

Substitute the given points (3,a) and (7,1) and the slope -34 into the formula:

1-a7-3=-34

1-a4=-34

Multiply both sides by 4:

1-a=-3

-a=-4

a=4
questions.score_improvement_tip: The slope formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac></math> is fundamental. Plug in the given coordinates and slope to solve for the unknown coordinate.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='80' cy='80' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='100' cy='95' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='120' cy='110' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='140' cy='125' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='160' cy='140' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='180' cy='155' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='200' cy='170' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='220' cy='185' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='240' cy='200' r='4' fill='blue'/><circle cx='260' cy='215' r='4' fill='blue'/><line x1='70' y1='70' x2='300' y2='230' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><text x='350' y='265' font-size='14' text-anchor='end'>Study Hours</text><text x='20' y='60' font-size='14' transform='rotate(-90 20,60)' text-anchor='end'>Test Score</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot with 10 data points showing a strong negative linear relationship between Study Hours and Test Score. A dashed red line approximates the trend, sloping downwards from left to right.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between the number of hours students studied for a test and their test scores. A line of best fit is shown. Based on the line, which of the following is the best interpretation of the slope?

options.A: For each additional hour studied, the test score increases by about <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>5</mn></math> points.
options.B: For each additional hour studied, the test score decreases by about <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>5</mn></math> points.
options.C: For each additional point on the test, the number of hours studied increases by about <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>5</mn></math>.
options.D: For each additional point on the test, the number of hours studied decreases by about <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>5</mn></math>.

questions.explanation: The slope of a line in a scatterplot of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math> (test score) versus <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> (study hours) represents the change in <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math> for a one-unit increase in <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>. The line has a negative slope (downward trend), meaning as study hours increase, test scores decrease. Visually, the slope appears to be about <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></math> (for each increase of 1 hour, the score drops about 5 points). Therefore, the best interpretation is B.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The slope in a scatterplot of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math> vs. <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> is 'change in <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math> per unit change in <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>.' The sign of the slope indicates the direction of the association (positive or negative).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='250' viewBox='0 0 400 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='250' fill='white'/><polygon points='30,220 350,220 220,60' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='220' y1='60' x2='220' y2='220' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='210,220 210,210 220,210' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><text x='15' y='225' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='360' y='225' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='215' y='50' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='215' y='240' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>D</text><text x='40' y='205' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>(3x+10)°</text><text x='170' y='110' font-family='serif' font-size='14' text-anchor='end'>(4x-18)°</text><text x='280' y='205' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>(2x+5)°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle ABC with altitude CD drawn to side AB. Angle A is labeled (3x + 10) degrees. Angle ACD is labeled (4x - 18) degrees. Angle B is labeled (2x + 5) degrees.
questions.question: In triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is an altitude to side <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>. If the measure of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>A</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>, the measure of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>, and the measure of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the measure of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>B</mi></math> in degrees?
questions.explanation:
First, focus on the right triangle ADC. Because CD is an altitude, ∠ADC=90°. This means the acute angles ∠A and ∠ACD are complementary (sum to 90°).

Set up the equation:
(3x+10)+(4x-18)=90

Combine like terms:
7x-8=90

Solve for x:
7x=98
x=14

Finally, substitute x=14 into the expression for ∠B:
∠B=2(14)+5=28+5=33°.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='250' viewBox='0 0 400 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='250' fill='white'/><polygon points='30,220 350,220 220,60' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='220' y1='60' x2='220' y2='220' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='210,220 210,210 220,210' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><text x='15' y='225' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='360' y='225' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='215' y='50' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='215' y='240' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>D</text><text x='60' y='205' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='blue'>52°</text><text x='180' y='110' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='blue' text-anchor='end'>38°</text><text x='290' y='205' font-family='serif' font-weight='bold' font-size='16' fill='green'>33°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same triangle with the calculated values substituted back in: Angle A is 52 degrees, Angle ACD is 38 degrees (summing to 90), and the answer Angle B is 33 degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Do not stop after finding <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>. Always double-check which variable or angle the question is actually asking for (in this case, Angle B).
